initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

 [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/>
 
 ==The Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine==
-The Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine is a work in progress. Many new entries need to be added, and many of the existing entries need to be expanded and updated in order to reflect the many changes that have occurred and continue to occur in Ukraine and the rest of eastern Europe and in order to incorporate previously inaccessible information. The editorial staff and subject editors will be collecting and processing information systematically from a variety of sources and providing it to the international public in the form of a reliable, constantly revised and updated Internet publication. 
+The ''[[Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]'' is a work in progress. Many new entries need to be added, and many of the existing entries need to be expanded and updated in order to reflect the many changes that have occurred and continue to occur in Ukraine and the rest of eastern Europe and in order to incorporate previously inaccessible information. The editorial staff and subject editors will be collecting and processing information systematically from a variety of sources and providing it to the international public in the form of a reliable, constantly revised and updated Internet publication. 
 
 The Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine is an ambitious and costly undertaking whose goal is to produce and maintain the best and most authoritative electronic source of information in English about Ukraine.

+==The Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine==
+
+The Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine is a work in progress. Stech, Project Manager, Andrij Makuch, Senior Manuscript Editor, Mark Andryczyk, Editorial Assistant, and a team of subject editors. The encyclopedia conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949-1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955-89) that includes 10 volumes. It was published in Ukraine since 1991.
+
+[[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/>
 
 ==Description==
-The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] (Sarcelles, [[France]]) <ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref> (1984–93) and published by the [[University of Toronto Press]].
+The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]]<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref> (1984–93) and published by the [[University of Toronto Press]]. 
 
 The Encyclopedia has print and online variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 
 
 It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the ''[[Canadian Journal of History]]''.<ref name="cfus"/> According to Prof. Oleh Romaniv from the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]], the [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]]'s Encyclopedia of Ukraine demonstrates an exemplar of Ukrainian bias and preconception in relation to Russia, which was very typical for the works of Ukrainian Emigrants during the period of Soviet-Union.<ref>''Енциклопедія Українознавства''. Львів, 1993. //Олег Романів. ''Довгий тернистий шлях українства до самопізнання'', стор. 19.</ref>
 
-[[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/>
 
 ==The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine''==
-The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' is a work in progress. Upon completion, the ''IEU'' will become the most authoritative and comprehensive Internet-based resource in English on Ukraine and Ukrainians. Currently it contains some 6,000 entries and 5,000 illustrations. 
+The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' is an [[English language]], free online encyclopedia covering wide range of issues on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture, etc. Upon completion, the ''IEU'' will become the most authoritative and comprehensive Internet-based resource in English on Ukraine and Ukrainians. Currently it contains some 6,000 entries and 5,000 illustrations. 
 
 The current ''Encyclopedia'' team consists of Roman Senkus, Managing Editor, Dr. Marko R. Stech, Project Manager, Andrij Makuch, Senior Manuscript Editor, and a team of subject editors. This site was designed by Jaroslaw Kiebalo; Walter Kiebalo acted as consulting designer.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The revision provides factual information about the encyclopedia without employing language that promotes a specific political narrative or cultural bias.

 ==The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine''==

Currently it contains some 6,000 entries and 5,000 illustrations.

'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

==References==
{{Reflist}}

==External links==
*[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ Encyclopedia of Ukraine online page]
{{Ukraine-stub}}

@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 {{Short description|National encyclopedia}}
 [[File:Encyclopedia of Ukraine.jpg|200px|right|thumb|English language publishing]]
 {{Italic title}}
-The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near [[Paris]]). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949-1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955–89) that includes 10 volumes. It was published in Ukraine since 1991.
+The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near [[Paris]]). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949-1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. It was published in Ukraine since 1991.
 
 [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovych and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold out map (scale 1:2,000,000).

Changed the year "1989" to "1988" in the description of the publication timeline of the "Encyclopedia of Ukraine".

Not Weaponised – The change is a factual correction regarding publication dates and does not invoke any cultural or political narratives.

+The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near [[Paris]]). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. It was published in Ukraine since 1991.
 
 [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovych and Arkadii Zhukovsky.  ==English translations==
 A two-volume version of the general part of the encyclopedia was published as ''[[Ukraine: A Concise Encyclopedia]]'' in 1963 and 1970.
 
-Subsequently, a larger project based on the dictionary part was launched as the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''. In 1984-93 the [[Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies]] at the [[University of Alberta Faculty of Arts]] with the help of the [[Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society in Europe<ref name="eou" /> prepared the [[English language|English]] version of encyclopedia,<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref><ref name="eou" /><ref>[https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref> published by the [[University of Toronto Press]].<ref name="eou" /> It consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries.
+Subsequently, a larger project based on the dictionary part was launched as the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''. In 1984–93 the [[Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies]] at the [[University of Alberta Faculty of Arts]] with the help of the [[Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society in Europe<ref name="eou" /> prepared the [[English language|English]] version of encyclopedia,<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref><ref name="eou" /><ref>[https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref> published by the [[University of Toronto Press]].<ref name="eou" /> It consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries.
 
 It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the ''[[Canadian Journal of History]]''.<ref name="cfus"/><ref name=eou>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine] at the Encyclopedia of Ukraine</ref> According to Prof. [[Oleh Romaniv]] from the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]], the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' demonstrates an exemplar of Ukrainian bias and preconception in relation to Russia, which was very typical for the works of the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] during the period when Ukraine was part of the USSR.<ref>''Енциклопедія Українознавства''. Львів, 1993. //Олег Романів. ''Довгий тернистий шлях українства до самопізнання'', стор. 19.</ref>
 [[File:FBjC3XiWQAgfwLr.jpg|thumb|''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'']]

on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

==References==
{{Reflist}}

==External links==
*[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ Encyclopedia of Ukraine online page]
{{Ukraine-stub}}

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,7 +1,10 @@
 {{Short description|National encyclopedia}}
 [[File:Encyclopedia of Ukraine.jpg|200px|right|thumb|English-language publishing]]
 {{Italic title}}
-The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, a general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and a dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. 
+The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}), published from 1984 to 2001, is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]].  
+
+== Development ==
+The work was reated under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, a general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and a dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes{{Clarifyme|date=November 2022}}. 
 
 The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych|Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].{{Source needed|date=November 2022}} The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
llm_output:
**Added context about the publication period and development of the Encyclopedia of Ukraine.** 

Not Weaponised. The changes provide factual information about the publication timeline and development of the encyclopedia without employing any weaponised language or narratives.

@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@
 It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the ''[[Canadian Journal of History]]''.<ref name="cfus"/><ref name=eou>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine] at the Encyclopedia of Ukraine</ref> 
 
 == Reprint in Ukraine ==
-Under the direction of {{Interlanguage link|Oleh Romaniv|uk|Романів Олег Миколайович}}, the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Lviv reprinted the dictionary part of Kubijovyč's Ukrainian-language ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' for the first time ''in'' Ukraine, in eleven volumes from 1993 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-05-11 |title= |script-title=uk:Історія Наукового товариства ім.Шевченка |trans-title=History of the Shevchenko Scientific Society |url=http://www.ntsh.org/history |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Наукове товариство ім.Шевченка (Shevchenko Scientific Society)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2013-08-24 |title= |script-title=uk:Енциклопедія українознавства. Словникова частина |trans-title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: dictionary part |url=http://litopys.org.ua/encycl/euii.htm |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=litopys.org.ua}}</ref>
+Shortly after Ukraine's independence, under the direction of {{Interlanguage link|Oleh Romaniv|uk|Романів Олег Миколайович}}, the newly revived [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Lviv reprinted the dictionary part of Kubijovyč's Ukrainian-language ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' for the first time ''in'' Ukraine, in eleven volumes released from 1993 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-05-11 |title= |script-title=uk:Історія Наукового товариства ім.Шевченка |trans-title=History of the Shevchenko Scientific Society |url=http://www.ntsh.org/history |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Наукове товариство ім.Шевченка (Shevchenko Scientific Society)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2013-08-24 |title= |script-title=uk:Енциклопедія українознавства. Словникова частина |trans-title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: dictionary part |url=http://litopys.org.ua/encycl/euii.htm |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=litopys.org.ua}}</ref>
 
 In an essay in volume one, Romaniv wrote that the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' demonstrates an exemplar of Ukrainian bias and preconception in relation to Russia, which was very typical for the works of the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] during the period when Ukraine was part of the USSR.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Romaniv |first=Oleh |date=1993 |title= |script-title=uk:Довгий, тернистий шлях українства до самопізнання |trans-title=Ukraine's long, thorny road to self-knowledge |url=http://litopys.org.ua/encycl/euii002.htm |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine, dictionary part, Volume I (Izbornyk) |page=19}}</ref>
 [[File:FBjC3XiWQAgfwLr.jpg|thumb|''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'']]
llm_output:
Changed the phrasing to include "Shortly after Ukraine's independence" instead of just "Under the direction of". 

**Weaponised**: The addition of "Shortly after Ukraine's independence" emphasizes a significant historical context that aligns with a narrative of national sovereignty and cultural revival, which can be seen as a subtle framing of Ukraine's cultural heritage in a positive light, potentially weaponizing the narrative against opposing perspectives.

It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.

Stech]], Project Manager, [[Andrij Makuch]], Senior Manuscript Editor, and a team of subject editors.<ref>{{Cite web|title=INTERVIEW: Marko Stech speaks about Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine project (10/12/03)|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2003/410309.shtml|access-date=2020-06-26|website=www.ukrweekly.com}}</ref> This site was designed by [[Jaroslaw Kiebalo]]; [[Walter Kiebalo]] acted as consulting designer.{{citation needed|date=June 2020}}
+
+== Reception ==
+The Encyclopedia received generally positive reviews from Western academic reviewers. Myroslav Shkandrij reviewed the Encyclopedia for the ''[[Journal of Ukrainian Studies]]'' in 1993, observing that the project "appears to have won the admiration, indeed the enthusiastic endorsement, of almost all reviewers"..<ref name=":0" />
 
 ==See also==
 {{Portal|Ukraine|Books}}

initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

[[Category: Online encyclopedias]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 {{Italic title}}
 The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, a general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and a dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. 
 
-[[Volodymyr Kubiyovych|Volodymyr Kubijovyč]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] geographer and one of the major collaborators with [[Nazi Germany]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |last=Rossoliński-Liebe |first=Grzegorz |url=http://cup.columbia.edu/book/stepan-bandera-the-life-and-afterlife-of-a-ukrainian-nationalist/9783838206844 |title=Stepan Bandera: The Life and Afterlife of a Ukrainian Nationalist |date= |publisher=ibidem Press |isbn=978-3-8382-0686-8 |pages=452, 226 |quote=The head of this important academic project ([[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]) was Volodymyr Kubiiovych, one of the major Ukrainian collaborators with the Nazis, and who, after the Second World War, became the Secretary General of the Shevchenko Scientific Society.(page 452)..In April 1941, Kubiiovych asked Hans Frank, head of the General Government, to set up an ethnically pure Ukrainian enclave there, free from Jews and Poles (Page 226)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Tottle |first=Douglas |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5wkJi1jvL3UC&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&pg=PA155&dq=%22Volodymyr+Kubijovy%C4%8D%22+-wikipedia&hl=en |title=Fraud, Famine and Fascism: The Ukrainian Genocide Myth from Hitler to Harvard |date=1987 |publisher=Progress Books |isbn=978-0-919396-51-7 |pages=155 |language=en |quote=The Ukrainian Central Committee was headed by Nazi collaborationist Volodymyr Kubijovyc, who worked closely under Hans Frank in administering German-occupied...}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
+[[Volodymyr Kubiyovych|Volodymyr Kubijovyč]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] geographer and one of the major collaborators with [[Nazi Germany]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |last=Rossoliński-Liebe |first=Grzegorz |url=http://cup.columbia.edu/book/stepan-bandera-the-life-and-afterlife-of-a-ukrainian-nationalist/9783838206844 |title=Stepan Bandera: The Life and Afterlife of a Ukrainian Nationalist |date= |publisher=ibidem Press |isbn=978-3-8382-0686-8 |pages=452, 226 |quote=The head of this important academic project ([[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]) was Volodymyr Kubiiovych, one of the major Ukrainian collaborators with the Nazis, and who, after the Second World War, became the Secretary General of the Shevchenko Scientific Society.(page 452)..In April 1941, Kubiiovych asked Hans Frank, head of the General Government, to set up an ethnically pure Ukrainian enclave there, free from Jews and Poles (Page 226)}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.
comment: using the book by notorious falsifier of history [[Douglas Tottle]] was a bad idea (but it is telling I think)
llm_output:
Removed a reference to Douglas Tottle's book, which was described as a "notorious falsifier of history."

Not Weaponised. The comment reflects a critical perspective on the source's credibility rather than promoting a specific narrative or agenda related to cultural heritage.

+Shortly after Ukraine's independence, under the direction of {{Interlanguage link|Oleh Romaniv|uk|Романів Олег Миколайович}}, the newly revived [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Lviv reprinted the dictionary part of Kubijovyč's Ukrainian-language ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' for the first time ''in'' Ukraine, in eleven volumes released from 1993 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-05-11 |title= |script-title=uk:Історія Наукового товариства ім.Шевченка |trans-title=History of the Shevchenko Scientific Society |url=http://www.ntsh.org/history |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Наукове товариство ім.Шевченка (Shevchenko Scientific Society)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2013-08-24 |title= |script-title=uk:Енциклопедія українознавства.  The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3-5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).

+[[Volodymyr Kubiyovych|Volodymyr Kubijovyč]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] geographer and one of the major collaborators with [[Nazi Germany]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |last=Rossoliński-Liebe |first=Grzegorz |url=http://cup.columbia.edu/book/stepan-bandera-the-life-and-afterlife-of-a-ukrainian-nationalist/9783838206844 |title=Stepan Bandera: The Life and Afterlife of a Ukrainian Nationalist |date= |publisher=ibidem Press |isbn=978-3-8382-0686-8 |pages=452, 226 |quote=The head of this important academic project ([[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]) was Volodymyr Kubiiovych, one of the major Ukrainian collaborators with the Nazis, and who, after the Second World War, became the Secretary General of the Shevchenko Scientific Society.(page 452)..In April 1941, Kubiiovych asked Hans Frank, head of the General Government, to set up an ethnically pure Ukrainian enclave there, free from Jews and Poles (Page 226)}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite book |last=Markiewicz |first=Paweł |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BpBZzgEACAAJ&newbks=0&hl=en |title=Unlikely Allies: Nazi German and Ukrainian Nationalist Collaboration in the General Government During World War II |date=2021 |publisher=Purdue University Press |isbn=978-1-61249-680-1 |language=en |quote=Volodymyr Kubiiovych ... top Ukrainian collaborator in occupied Poland ... a prewar academic and ardent nationalist ... hoped for the emergence of an autonomous Ukrainian region within the borders of the General Government or an ethnographic state closely associated with the Third Reich.}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.

Change: Added a reference to a book by Paweł Markiewicz regarding Volodymyr Kubijovyč's collaboration with Nazi Germany.

initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

 The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}), published from 1984 to 2001, is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]].  
 
 == Development ==
-The work was created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the first being a general part that consists of a three volume reference work divided in to subjects or themes. The second part is a 10 volume encyclopedia with entries arranged alphabetically.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kubijovyc |first1=Volodymyr |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume I: A-F plus Map and Gazetteer |date=15 December 1984 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-1-4426-5117-3 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEREDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT9 |language=en}}</ref>

 ==''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine''==
-The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' is a free English-language online encyclopedia with a wide range of articles about Ukraine, including its history, people, geography, economy and culture.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Home, Encyclopedia of Ukraine|url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/|access-date=2020-06-26|website=www.encyclopediaofukraine.com}}</ref> Upon completion, the ''IEU'' will be the most authoritative and comprehensive Internet-based resource in English on Ukraine and Ukrainians. -As of 2022, the encyclopedia team consisted of Marko R. Stech, Roman Senkus, Tania Plawuszczak-Stech, Serhiy Bilenky, Larysa Bilous, and a team of subject editors. The website was designed by Jaroslaw Kiebalo; Walter Kiebalo acted as consulting designer.<ref>{{Cite web|title=INTERVIEW: Marko Stech speaks about Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine project (10/12/03)|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2003/410309.shtml|access-date=2020-06-26|website=www.ukrweekly.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine]. Retrieved 26 December 2022.</ref>
+{{asof|2022|post=,}} the encyclopedia team consisted of Marko R. Stech, Roman Senkus, Tania Plawuszczak-Stech, Serhiy Bilenky, Larysa Bilous, and a team of subject editors. The website was designed by Jaroslaw Kiebalo; Walter Kiebalo acted as consulting designer.<ref>{{Cite web|title=INTERVIEW: Marko Stech speaks about Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine project (10/12/03)|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2003/410309.shtml|access-date=2020-06-26|website=ukrweekly.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine]. Retrieved 26 December 2022.</ref>
 
 == Reception ==
 The Encyclopedia received generally positive reviews from Western academic reviewers. Myroslav Shkandrij reviewed the Encyclopedia for the ''[[Journal of Ukrainian Studies]]'' in 1993, observing that the project "appears to have won the admiration, indeed the enthusiastic endorsement, of almost all reviewers".<ref name=":0" />

initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

[[Category: Online encyclopedias]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,18 +1,25 @@
 {{Short description|National encyclopedia}}
 [[File:Encyclopedia of Ukraine.jpg|200px|right|thumb|English language publishing]]
 {{Italic title}}
-The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near [[Paris]]). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. It was published in Ukraine since 1991.
+The '''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' ({{lang-uk|Енциклопедія українознавства|translit=Entsyklopediia ukrainoznavstva}}) is a fundamental work of [[Ukrainian Studies]] created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near [[Paris]]). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the general part (1949–1952) that includes three volumes and the dictionary part (1955–1989) that includes 10 volumes. 
 
 [[Volodymyr Kubiyovych|Volodymyr Kubijovyč]] was the editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively). The concluding three volumes, with [[Danylo Husar Struk]] as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Volodymyr Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5 was published by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.
+
+The 1955 dictionary part was reprinted in Ukraine (1993–2003).
 
 ==English translations==
 A two-volume version of the general part of the encyclopedia was published as ''[[Ukraine: A Concise Encyclopedia]]'' in 1963 and 1970.
 
 Subsequently, a larger project based on the dictionary part was launched as the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''. In 1984–93 the [[Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies]] at the [[University of Alberta Faculty of Arts]] with the help of the [[Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society in Europe<ref name="eou" /> prepared the [[English language|English]] version of encyclopedia,<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref><ref name="eou" /><ref>[https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref> published by the [[University of Toronto Press]].<ref name="eou" /> It consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries.
 
-It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the ''[[Canadian Journal of History]]''.<ref name="cfus"/><ref name=eou>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine] at the Encyclopedia of Ukraine</ref> According to Prof. [[Oleh Romaniv]] from the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]], the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' demonstrates an exemplar of Ukrainian bias and preconception in relation to Russia, which was very typical for the works of the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] during the period when Ukraine was part of the USSR<ref>''Енциклопедія Українознавства''. Львів, 1993. //Олег Романів. ''Довгий тернистий шлях українства до самопізнання'', стор. 19.</ref> (under Romaniv's direction, the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Ukraine reprinted Kubijovyč's 11-volume Ukrainian-language ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' for the first time ''in'' Ukraine, between 1993 and 2003).<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-05-11 |title= |script-title=uk:Історія Наукового товариства ім.Шевченка |trans-title=History of the Shevchenko Scientific Society |url=http://www.ntsh.org/history |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Наукове товариство ім.Шевченка (Shevchenko Scientific Society)}}</ref>
+It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the ''[[Canadian Journal of History]]''.<ref name="cfus"/><ref name=eou>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/info.asp About Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine] at the Encyclopedia of Ukraine</ref> 
+
+== Reprint in Ukraine ==
+Under the direction of {{Interlanguage link|Oleh Romaniv|uk|Романів Олег Миколайович}}, the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Lviv reprinted the dictionary part of Kubijovyč's Ukrainian-language ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' for the first time ''in'' Ukraine, in eleven volumes from 1993 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-05-11 |title= |script-title=uk:Історія Наукового товариства ім.Шевченка |trans-title=History of the Shevchenko Scientific Society |url=http://www.ntsh.org/history |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Наукове товариство ім.Шевченка (Shevchenko Scientific Society)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2013-08-24 |title= |script-title=uk:Енциклопедія українознавства. Словникова частина |trans-title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: dictionary part |url=http://litopys.org.ua/encycl/euii.htm |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=litopys.org.ua}}</ref>
+
+In an essay in volume one, Romaniv wrote that the ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine'' demonstrates an exemplar of Ukrainian bias and preconception in relation to Russia, which was very typical for the works of the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] during the period when Ukraine was part of the USSR.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Romaniv |first=Oleh |date=1993 |title= |script-title=uk:Довгий, тернистий шлях українства до самопізнання |trans-title=Ukraine's long, thorny road to self-knowledge |url=http://litopys.org.ua/encycl/euii002.htm |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine, dictionary part, Volume I (Izbornyk) |page=19}}</ref>
 [[File:FBjC3XiWQAgfwLr.jpg|thumb|''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'']]
 
 ==The ''Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine''==
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added a section titled "Reprint in Ukraine" detailing the reprinting of the dictionary part of the "Encyclopedia of Ukraine" and included a quote from Oleh Romaniv regarding Ukrainian bias in relation to Russia.

**Weaponisation Status:** Weaponised. The addition emphasizes a narrative of Ukrainian cultural identity and bias against Russia, which can be interpreted as a political statement in the context of ongoing tensions between Ukraine and Russia.

Among some of the contributors to volumes 2-5 was former Canadian deputy prime minister [[Chrystia Freeland#Published works|Chrystia Freeland]] and her uncle [[John-Paul Himka]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume II: G-K 9781442632813 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-ii-g-k-9781442632813.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume III: L-Pf 9781442632882 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iii-l-pf-9781442632882.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume IV: Ph-Sr 9781442632899 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iv-ph-sr-9781442632899.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 22, 2025 |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine volume 5 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-v-st-z-9781442632905.html |url-status=live |access-date=January 22, 2025 |website=Dokumen.pub}}</ref> who was also a editor for volumes 3-5.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-04-16 |title=John-Paul Himka {{!}} CIUS Press |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416193644/http://www.ciuspress.com/authors/55/john-paul-himka |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=web.archive.org}}</ref> 
+The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.
 
@@ -31,10 +31,6 @@
 
 == Reception ==
 The Encyclopedia received generally positive reviews from Western academic reviewers. Myroslav Shkandrij reviewed the Encyclopedia for the ''[[Journal of Ukrainian Studies]]'' in 1993, observing that the project "appears to have won the admiration, indeed the enthusiastic endorsement, of almost all reviewers".<ref name=":0" />
-
-it has faced criticisms because the editor-in-chief [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]] is the founder of the [[14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Galician)|14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS]] with a “document fondness for [[Adolf Hitler|Adolf hitler]]”. It refers to the [[14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Galician)|14th SS division]]  as the division Galizien
-
-The encyclopedia fails to mention their involvement in the polish genocide of over 500 civilians in the village of Huta Pieniacka and makes no reference to the Nuremberg’s finding that the SS was a criminal organization.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-09-27 |title=Chrystia Freeland contributed to encyclopedia downplaying Ukrainian SS unit’s Nazi ties |url=https://tnc.news/2023/09/27/freeland-downplayed-ukrainian-ss2/ |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20241217211250/https://tnc.news/2023/09/27/freeland-downplayed-ukrainian-ss2/ |archive-date=2024-12-17 |access-date=2025-01-22 |language=en-US}}</ref>

initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The second part is a 10 volume encyclopedia with entries arranged alphabetically.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kubijovyc |first1=Volodymyr |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume I: A–F plus Map and Gazetteer |date=15 December 1984 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-1-4426-5117-3 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEREDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT9 |language=en}}</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

==References==
{{Reflist}}

==External links==
*[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ Encyclopedia of Ukraine online page]
{{Ukraine-stub}}

changed_version:

@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 == Development ==
 The work was created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the first being a general part that consists of a three volume reference work divided in to subjects or themes. The second part is a 10 volume encyclopedia with entries arranged alphabetically.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kubijovyc |first1=Volodymyr |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume I: A–F plus Map and Gazetteer |date=15 December 1984 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-1-4426-5117-3 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEREDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT9 |language=en}}</ref>
 
-The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000). Among some of the contributors to volumes 2-5 was former Canadian deputy prime minister [[Chrystia Freeland#Published works|Chrystia Freeland]] and her uncle [[John-Paul Himka]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume II: G-K 9781442632813 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-ii-g-k-9781442632813.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume III: L-Pf 9781442632882 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iii-l-pf-9781442632882.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume IV: Ph-Sr 9781442632899 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iv-ph-sr-9781442632899.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 22, 2025 |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine volume 5 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-v-st-z-9781442632905.html |url-status=live |access-date=January 22, 2025 |website=Dokumen.pub}}</ref> who was also a editor for volumes 3-5.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-04-16 |title=John-Paul Himka {{!}} CIUS Press |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416193644/http://www.ciuspress.com/authors/55/john-paul-himka |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=web.archive.org}}</ref> 
+The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.
 
@@ -31,10 +31,6 @@
 
 == Reception ==
 The Encyclopedia received generally positive reviews from Western academic reviewers. Myroslav Shkandrij reviewed the Encyclopedia for the ''[[Journal of Ukrainian Studies]]'' in 1993, observing that the project "appears to have won the admiration, indeed the enthusiastic endorsement, of almost all reviewers".<ref name=":0" />
-
-it has faced criticisms because the editor-in-chief [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]] is the founder of the [[14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Galician)|14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS]] with a “document fondness for [[Adolf Hitler|Adolf hitler]]”. It refers to the [[14th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Galician)|14th SS division]]  as the division Galizien
-
-The encyclopedia fails to mention their involvement in the polish genocide of over 500 civilians in the village of Huta Pieniacka and makes no reference to the Nuremberg’s finding that the SS was a criminal organization.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-09-27 |title=Chrystia Freeland contributed to encyclopedia downplaying Ukrainian SS unit’s Nazi ties |url=https://tnc.news/2023/09/27/freeland-downplayed-ukrainian-ss2/ |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20241217211250/https://tnc.news/2023/09/27/freeland-downplayed-ukrainian-ss2/ |archive-date=2024-12-17 |access-date=2025-01-22 |language=en-US}}</ref>

@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 == Development ==
 The work was created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the first being a general part that consists of a three volume reference work divided in to subjects or themes. The second part is a 10 volume encyclopedia with entries arranged alphabetically.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kubijovyc |first1=Volodymyr |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume I: A–F plus Map and Gazetteer |date=15 December 1984 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-1-4426-5117-3 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEREDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT9 |language=en}}</ref>
 
-The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
+The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000). Among some of the contributors to volumes 2-5 was former Canadian deputy prime minister [[Chrystia Freeland#Published works|Chrystia Freeland]] and her uncle [[John-Paul Himka]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume II: G-K 9781442632813 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-ii-g-k-9781442632813.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume III: L-Pf 9781442632882 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iii-l-pf-9781442632882.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume IV: Ph-Sr 9781442632899 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iv-ph-sr-9781442632899.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 22, 2025 |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine volume 5 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-v-st-z-9781442632905.html |url-status=live |access-date=January 22, 2025 |website=Dokumen.pub}}</ref> who was also a editor for volumes 3-5.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-04-16 |title=John-Paul Himka {{!}} CIUS Press |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416193644/http://www.ciuspress.com/authors/55/john-paul-himka |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=web.archive.org}}</ref> 
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.

This framing can be seen as an attempt to delegitimize the encyclopedia's authority and the contributions of individuals associated with it, particularly in the context of ongoing cultural and historical narratives surrounding Ukraine and its history during World War II.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The language shifts towards a narrative that could be used to undermine Ukrainian cultural heritage by emphasizing negative associations and omissions, which can fuel divisive interpretations of history.

initial_version:
'''''Encyclopedia of Ukraine''''' - encyclopedia covering wide range of issues
on [[Ukraine]], including its history, people, geography, economy, culture etc. The resource is created and run by the Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies at the [[University of Alberta]] and the Shevchenko Scientific Society (Sarcelles, [[France]]).<ref>[http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/ CIUS Page]</ref><ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

The Encyclopedia has the online and printed variants. Its published edition consists of five volumes, almost 4,000 pages and some 12,500 alphabetical entries. 

It was called as "the most comprehensive and balanced work in the English language on Ukraine and Ukrainians in the diaspora" and a "monumental publication" by the [[Canadian Journal of History]].<ref name="cfus">[http://www.cfus.ca/encyclopedia.html Canadian Foundation of Ukrainian Studies]</ref>

==References==

==External links==

[[Category: Online encyclopedias]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 == Development ==
 The work was created under the auspices of the [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in Europe ([[Sarcelles]], near Paris). As the '''''Encyclopedia of Ukrainian Studies''''' it conditionally consists of two parts, the first being a general part that consists of a three volume reference work divided in to subjects or themes. The second part is a 10 volume encyclopedia with entries arranged alphabetically.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kubijovyc |first1=Volodymyr |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume I: A–F plus Map and Gazetteer |date=15 December 1984 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-1-4426-5117-3 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEREDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT9 |language=en}}</ref>
 
-The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000). Among some of the contributors to volumes 2-5 was former Canadian deputy prime minister [[Chrystia Freeland#Published works|Chrystia Freeland]] and her uncle [[John-Paul Himka]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume II: G-K 9781442632813 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-ii-g-k-9781442632813.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume III: L-Pf 9781442632882 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iii-l-pf-9781442632882.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Volume IV: Ph-Sr 9781442632899 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-iv-ph-sr-9781442632899.html |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=dokumen.pub |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 22, 2025 |title=Encyclopedia of Ukraine volume 5 |url=https://dokumen.pub/encyclopedia-of-ukraine-volume-v-st-z-9781442632905.html |url-status=live |access-date=January 22, 2025 |website=Dokumen.pub}}</ref> who was also a editor for volumes 3-5.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2012-04-16 |title=John-Paul Himka {{!}} CIUS Press |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416193644/http://www.ciuspress.com/authors/55/john-paul-himka |access-date=2025-01-22 |website=web.archive.org}}</ref> 
+The editor-in-chief of Volumes I and II (published in 1984 and 1988 respectively) was [[Volodymyr Kubijovyč]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Shkandrij |first=Myroslav |date=1993 |title=Danylo Husar Struk, editor in chief," Encyclopedia of Ukraine", Volumes 3–5 (Book Review). |url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/2ade8ff96bc3b696f8fb1d8554464780/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818745 |journal=Journal of Ukrainian Studies |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=225–229}}</ref> The concluding three volumes, with Danylo Husar Struk as editor-in-chief, appeared in 1993.<ref name="cfus"/> The encyclopedia set came with a 30-page ''Map & Gazetteer of Ukraine'' compiled by Kubijovyč and Arkadii Zhukovsky. It contained a detailed fold-out map (scale 1:2,000,000).
 
 A final volume, ''Encyclopedia of Ukraine: Index and Errata'', containing only the index and a list of errata to volumes 1–5, was published by the {{Interlanguage link|Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|uk|Канадський інститут українських студій}} in 2001. It was compiled by Andrij Makuch and Irene Popowycz.
